verses.text: Then I was given a measuring rod like a staff, and someone said, 'Rise and measure the temple of God and the altar, and those who worship there.'
verses.comment: The measuring of the temple is symbolic, recalling Old Testament visions where prophets measured holy places (see Ezekiel 40:3-4; Zechariah 2:1). This could be understood as an act of preservation, signifying holiness, and preparation for divine visitation.

verses.text: But leave out the courtyard which is outside the temple, and do not measure it, because it has been given to the nations, and they will trample the holy city for forty-two months.
verses.comment: The outer court being given to the nations represents a period when the faithful endure persecution, echoing Daniel 7:25 and Luke 21:24. The forty-two months (three and a half years) points to a limited time of suffering, commonly interpreted as a test of faith and perseverance.

verses.text: And I will grant to my two witnesses, and they will prophesy for one thousand two hundred sixty days, clothed in sackcloth.
verses.comment: The two witnesses recall prophetic figures like Moses and Elijah (see Zech. 4:3), bearing testimony through suffering (sackcloth), a sign of repentance and humility. The number of days matches the forty-two months, underscoring persistent witness during tribulation.

verses.text: These are the two olive trees and the two lampstands that stand before the Lord of the earth.
verses.comment: Drawing on Zechariah 4:2-14, olive trees and lampstands symbolize anointed ones who bear God's light and Spirit. Standing before the Lord suggests authority and a continual priestly or prophetic ministry, an image tied historically to apostolic succession.

verses.text: If anyone tries to harm them, fire comes out from their mouths and devours their enemies. Anyone wanting to harm them must be killed in this way.
verses.comment: Their divinely given power echoes Elijah (2 Kings 1:10) and demonstrates God’s protection of true witnesses. Fire as judgment refers to prophetic authority and the vindication of the faithful.

verses.text: They have authority to shut the sky so that no rain may fall during the days of their prophecy, and they have authority over the waters to turn them into blood and to strike the earth with every kind of plague, as often as they desire.
verses.comment: The witnesses perform Moses (Exodus 7:14-21) and Elijah (1 Kings 17:1) style miracles. Their authority is reminiscent of the prophetic office’s power to call down judgment, placing the Church’s apostles and prophets in a uniquely authoritative role.

verses.text: When they finish their testimony, the beast that comes up out of the abyss will make war on them, conquer them, and kill them.
verses.comment: The beast from the abyss signifies evil powers opposing God's witnesses, drawing from Daniel 7:21's persecution of the saints. Death here is temporary, alluding to Christ's passion and the suffering endured for faith.

verses.text: Their dead bodies will lie in the street of the great city, which is figuratively called Sodom and Egypt, where also their Lord was crucified.
verses.comment: The reference to Sodom and Egypt highlights the city’s spiritual corruption (Isa. 1:9; Ex. 7:1-5). Mention of their Lord’s crucifixion alludes to Jerusalem (Luke 23:33), connecting the witnesses’ suffering to Christ’s own.

verses.text: For three and a half days, some from the peoples, tribes, languages, and nations look at their dead bodies and refuse to let them be buried.
verses.comment: The time period, three and a half days, parallels the three and a half years previously mentioned. Denying burial symbolizes utter contempt, yet foreshadows resurrection.

verses.text: Those who dwell on the earth will rejoice over them and make merry, and exchange gifts, because these two prophets had tormented those who dwell on the earth.
verses.comment: The celebration over the prophets’ deaths highlights the world’s hostility toward God’s messengers, reflecting the opposition to truth that believers face in every era.

verses.text: But after the three and a half days, the breath of life from God entered them, and they stood up on their feet, and great fear fell on those who saw them.
verses.comment: Resurrection is depicted using imagery from Ezekiel 37:10, foreshadowing the promise of future resurrection embodied in Christ (Matt. 28:6). Breath of life points to the work of the Spirit, commonly interpreted as a mystery realized in the Church’s sacramental life.

verses.text: And they heard a loud voice from heaven saying to them, 'Come up here.' And they went up to heaven in a cloud, while their enemies watched them.
verses.comment: Their ascension recalls Christ’s own (Acts 1:9), suggesting a vindication and glorification for those united to Him, emphasizing the promise of heavenly reward for those who persevere.

verses.text: At that hour there was a great earthquake, and a tenth of the city fell; seven thousand people were killed in the earthquake. The rest were terrified and gave glory to the God of heaven.
verses.comment: The earthquake is often a sign of divine intervention (Ex. 19:18), and the survivors’ repentance hints at the efficacy of authentic witness, even through suffering.

verses.text: The second woe has passed; behold, the third woe is coming soon.
verses.comment: This marks the progression of judgment. Each woe heightens the anticipation of final justice, reminiscent of the prophetic cycles of warning and fulfillment.

verses.text: Then the seventh angel blew his trumpet, and loud voices in heaven said, 'The kingdom of the world has become the kingdom of our Lord and of his Christ, and he shall reign forever and ever.'
verses.comment: Christ's eternal reign fulfills Daniel 7:14 and Luke 1:33, confirming His everlasting kingship, often interpreted as inaugurated but awaiting final consummation. This signals both eschatological fulfillment and an ongoing reality in the visible Church.

verses.text: And the twenty-four elders, who sit on their thrones before God, fell on their faces and worshiped God,
verses.comment: The elders represent the fullness of God’s covenant people, worshipping in heavenly liturgy. Their posture reflects humble adoration, linking the worship of heaven to the worship on earth.

verses.text: saying, 'We give thanks to you, Lord God Almighty, who is and who was, for you have taken your great power and begun to reign.'
verses.comment: The elders’ praise alludes to God’s sovereignty (Ps. 97:1), with the phrase 'who is and who was' echoing God's eternity (Rev. 1:8). The beginning of reign aligns with the Church’s hope in Christ’s present authority and future completion.

verses.text: The nations were angry, and your wrath has come, and the time for the dead to be judged, and for rewarding your servants, the prophets and the saints, and those who fear your name, both small and great, and for destroying those who destroy the earth.
verses.comment: The judgment includes rewards for all who are devoted to God, emphasizing saints and prophets. The structure here underscores the unity of all faithful believers, both past and present, in hope of resurrection and reward.

verses.text: Then the temple of God in heaven was opened, and the ark of his covenant was seen within his temple. There were flashes of lightning, voices, peals of thunder, an earthquake, and great hail.
verses.comment: The opening of the heavenly temple and the revealing of the ark signifies the full revelation of God’s presence and covenant promises. Many see hints here of spiritual realities realized in sacred worship and the Eucharist, which is seen by some as the fulfillment of the old covenant symbols in the new era.
